summary: This is an FBI 302 interview summary of Dr. , the Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), conducted on August 29, 2019. Dr. details her psychological assessments and interactions with Jeffrey Epstein from his intake on July 8, 2019, through his time in custody, including the July 23 incident where he was found with a noose, his housing concerns, and her observations leading up to his death. The document provides insight into the psychological protocols, Epstein's behavior in jail, and potential systemic failures.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.role: Chief Psychologist at Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC)
persons.context: The interviewee who provided detailed information about the psychological intake process, suicide risk assessments, and her direct interactions with Jeffrey Epstein while he was incarcerated at MCC.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate charged with sex offenses who was under psychological observation at MCC. The document details his behavior, complaints, the July 23 noose incident, and his interactions with Dr. .

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him and called him a pedophile, leading to hypotheses about the July 23 incident being an assault, gaming, or a suicide rehearsal.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: A psychologist consulted by Dr. regarding Epstein's risk factors upon his intake. Also involved in discussions about Epstein's housing.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.role: National Suicide Prevention Coordinator from BOP Central Office
persons.context: Consulted by Dr. regarding Epstein's housing situation. Recommended housing Epstein with a sex offender in the SHU.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: A SHU Lieutenant to whom Dr. passed on Epstein's demands. Described as very regimented and regularly compliant with Dr. 's requests.

persons.name: Lt. Doctor
persons.context: Conducted an investigation into the possible assault on Epstein during the July 23 incident, which had not returned any answers by July 27.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: Present at executive staff meetings where inmates' psychological status was discussed. Involved in the decision regarding Epstein's initial SHU cellmate.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.context: Present at executive staff meetings. Involved in the decision regarding Epstein's initial SHU cellmate.

connections.description: Dr. was the chief psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological assessments, suicide risk evaluations, and daily welfare checks during his incarceration.
Were housed together in the SHU. Epstein accused Tartaglione of attempting to kill him and calling him a pedophile.
Dr. consulted with Dr. about Epstein's risk factors upon his intake to MCC.
Dr. consulted with Dr. , the National Suicide Prevention Coordinator, regarding Epstein's housing situation.
Dr. passed Epstein's complaints and demands to Lt. . She described him as regimented and compliant with her requests.

events.title: Epstein's Intake and Initial Assessment
events.description: Dr. completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ) for Jeffrey Epstein. Epstein marked nothing, but due to his high-profile case and sex offense charges, Dr. ordered he be placed on observation status for a thorough suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck and was placed on Suicide Watch. He told staff his cellmate, Tartaglione, tried to kill him. Dr. completed a suicide risk assessment and kept him on Suicide Watch.

events.title: Epstein Taken Off Suicide Watch
events.description: Dr. met with Epstein, who reported being fearful of returning to his cell with Tartaglione. Epstein denied being suicidal. Dr. took him off Suicide Watch and placed him on Psychological Observation.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Dr. transitioned Epstein back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) after he chose to stay in Psychological Observation one more night without his CPAP machine. An email was sent updating staff of his transition and the need for him to be housed with a cellmate.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a new will. Dr. stated that had Psychological Services been aware, it would have been considered a red flag and Epstein would have been placed on Psychological Observation. The attorneys did not inform Psychological Services.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY, 10007 (US Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Dr. , MCC's Chief Psychologist, conducted three suicide risk assessments on Jeffrey Epstein, which she noted was unusual.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a loose noose; he claimed his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him, but Dr. had three hypotheses: gaming by either inmate, a suicide rehearsal by Epstein, or an assault by Tartaglione.

Dr. stated that Epstein's attorneys never contacted Psychological Services with any mental health concerns, and they did not inform staff when Epstein signed a new will on August 8, which would have been a major red flag.

Dr. emphasized the importance of housing SHU inmates with a cellmate to decrease isolation, provide a distraction, and offer a rescue opportunity, noting that lack of a cellmate and understaffing contributed to Epstein's death.

The document reveals that regular rounds by correctional officers in the SHU were not being completed, a fact Dr. was unaware of because, as executive staff, officers would not tell her and inmates feared retaliation.
